Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story: I was in the middle of tracing a stubborn sensor fault on the main production line when my phone buzzed. It was my stepdad, his voice trembling. “Can you talk? I really need you right now.” He never called me at work unless it was serious. I could hear the weight in his words, the kind that made me want to drop everything and just listen, be the support he rarely asked for. But the factory floor was tense—every minute the line was down cost us more, and the supervisor’s eyes kept darting to the clock, silently urging me to hurry. I could almost feel the pressure of both worlds squeezing me. My stepdad needed me to be present, to care, to listen. My team needed me to fix the machine, to keep production moving. I stared at the blinking error code, my phone warm in my hand, torn between the family I was still learning to belong to and the job that demanded my focus. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which call to answer first.
